verses.text: Lord, God of my salvation, I cry out day and night before you.
verses.comment: This opening addresses God as the source of rescue and hope, showing personal devotion through persistent prayer.

verses.text: Let my prayer come before you; incline your ear to my cry.
verses.comment: The psalmist seeks God's attentive presence, echoing the faith that God listens to earnest supplication.

verses.text: For my soul is full of troubles, and my life draws near to Sheol.
verses.comment: Sheol represents the realm of the dead in Hebrew tradition, and the psalmist feels dangerously close to death.

verses.text: I am counted among those who go down to the pit; I am like a man without strength,
verses.comment: The pit is a poetic description of the grave or destruction, emphasizing the depth of the psalmist's despair.

verses.text: abandoned among the dead, like the slain who lie in the grave, whom you remember no more, for they are cut off from your hand.
verses.comment: There is a sense of separation from God, a motif echoed by Christ's own experience on the Cross (Matt. 27:46), highlighting the fullness of human suffering taken on by the Messiah.

verses.text: You have put me in the lowest pit, in dark places, in the depths.
verses.comment: The darkness and depth intensify the image of alienation, suggesting spiritual as well as physical suffering.

verses.text: Your wrath lies heavy upon me, and you have afflicted me with all your waves. Selah.
verses.comment: 'Selah' may indicate a pause for reflection. The experience of suffering under God's hand is reminiscent of the disciplinary role of suffering found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: You have taken my friends far from me; you have made me an abomination to them. I am shut in and cannot escape.
verses.comment: Isolation increases the psalmist's suffering. Such language anticipates the suffering Messiah who was forsaken by his followers (Matt. 26:56).

verses.text: My eyes grow weak from affliction; I call to you, Lord, every day; I spread out my hands to you.
verses.comment: The uplifted hands are a gesture of prayer and surrender, a pattern repeated in later Christian worship.

verses.text: Do you do wonders for the dead? Do the departed rise up to praise you? Selah.
verses.comment: A serious question about the possibility of praise after death. Hints at the hope for resurrection which becomes clearer in later revelation (1 Cor. 15:52-54).

verses.text: Is your steadfast love declared in the grave, or your faithfulness in Abaddon?
verses.comment: Abaddon refers to destruction or the place of the dead. Emphasizes loss without divine intervention—a sentiment fulfilled in Christ’s descent to the dead.

verses.text: Are your wonders known in the darkness, or your righteousness in the land of forgetfulness?
verses.comment: The 'land of forgetfulness' conveys both a literal death and spiritual oblivion—confirming the need for hope in God’s redemption.

verses.text: But I, O Lord, cry to you; in the morning my prayer comes before you.
verses.comment: The psalmist’s persistence in prayer exemplifies trust and faithfulness, anchoring this lament in hope.

verses.text: Lord, why do you cast off my soul? Why do you hide your face from me?
verses.comment: Language echoed by Jesus on the Cross (Matt. 27:46), revealing the depth of his identification with human suffering.

verses.text: Afflicted and close to death from my youth up, I suffer your terrors; I am helpless.
verses.comment: Even from early life, the psalmist experiences acute suffering, a theme of long-suffering that can be seen as a type or figure of Christ.

verses.text: Your fierce anger has swept over me; your terrors have destroyed me.
verses.comment: Suffering is attributed to God's righteous action; this deepens the sense of trust, suggesting that even affliction is within God's providential plan.

verses.text: They surround me like water all day long; they close in on me together.
verses.comment: Imagery of overwhelming waters symbolizes the psalmist's trouble. A metaphor for the spiritual trials faced in life.

verses.text: You have taken my companions and loved ones far from me; my only friend is darkness.
verses.comment: The psalm ends with unresolved sorrow, a rare lament in the Psalter. Yet it represents the honesty of faith and the endurance of hope, even in darkness. The reality of suffering and abandonment is met with perseverance in prayer—a pattern fulfilled perfectly in the life and passion of Christ, who draws all suffering into redemptive meaning through His Church and sacraments.
